claim: The United States has never defaulted on its national debt

supporting.text: The U.S. Treasury has always made timely payments on its debt obligations, including principal and interest, as required by law.

attacks.text: The U.S. Treasury has always made timely payments on its debt obligations, including principal and interest, as required by law.
The U.S. technically defaulted in 1979 due to delayed payments on Treasury bills caused by administrative errors.
The 1979 incident was a minor, temporary delay and not a true default, as all payments were eventually made with interest.
The U.S. came close to defaulting in 2011 and 2013 during debt ceiling crises, which required last-minute legislative action.
Near-defaults due to political brinkmanship do not constitute actual defaults, as payments were never missed.

supporting.text: Historical records show no instance where the U.S. government failed to meet its debt obligations, even during economic crises like the Great Depression.

attacks.text: Historical records show no instance where the U.S. government failed to meet its debt obligations, even during economic crises like the Great Depression.
The U.S. technically defaulted in 1979 due to administrative delays in processing Treasury bills, though the amounts were small and quickly resolved.
The 1979 incident was a temporary technical issue, not a true sovereign default, as all obligations were ultimately honored without restructuring or creditor losses.
Debt ceiling standoffs (e.g., 2011) created near-default scenarios where the U.S. prioritized some payments over others, effectively a selective default.
Prioritization of payments during debt ceiling crises maintained full payment to bondholders, preserving the legal definition of non-default on sovereign debt.

supporting.text: Credit rating agencies have consistently affirmed the U.S. government's ability and willingness to pay its debts, reflecting its strong track record.

attacks.text: Credit rating agencies have consistently affirmed the U.S. government's ability and willingness to pay its debts, reflecting its strong track record.
Credit rating agencies have been wrong before, such as during the 2008 financial crisis when they gave high ratings to mortgage-backed securities that later defaulted.
The 2008 crisis was a unique event involving complex financial instruments, whereas U.S. Treasury securities are straightforward and backed by the full faith and credit of the government.
The U.S. came close to defaulting in 2011 during the debt ceiling crisis, which led to a downgrade of its credit rating by S&P.
Despite the 2011 downgrade, the U.S. continued to meet all its debt obligations, and its borrowing costs remained low, indicating sustained market confidence.

supporting.text: The U.S. Constitution grants Congress the power to borrow money and pay debts, ensuring legal mechanisms exist to prevent default.

attacks.text: The U.S. Constitution grants Congress the power to borrow money and pay debts, ensuring legal mechanisms exist to prevent default.
Legal mechanisms do not guarantee practical execution; political gridlock or refusal to raise the debt ceiling could still lead to default.
Historical precedent shows Congress has always resolved debt ceiling crises before default, reinforcing the reliability of these mechanisms.
The 14th Amendment's debt clause has been interpreted as prohibiting default, but this has never been legally tested in a crisis.
Legal scholars widely agree the 14th Amendment obligates payment of debts, making default unconstitutional regardless of political disputes.

supporting.text: Even during political standoffs over the debt ceiling, temporary measures have been used to avoid default, maintaining the U.S.'s perfect repayment history.

attacks.text: Even during political standoffs over the debt ceiling, temporary measures have been used to avoid default, maintaining the U.S.'s perfect repayment history.
The U.S. has technically defaulted in the past, such as in 1979 when it delayed payments to some Treasury bill holders due to administrative errors.
The 1979 incident was a minor technical delay, not a true default, and all payments were made with interest shortly after.
Political brinkmanship over the debt ceiling increases the risk of future defaults, undermining confidence in the 'perfect repayment history' claim.
The U.S. government has consistently prioritized debt payments even during crises, demonstrating institutional safeguards against default.
